pullRequest.body:
Added `Field.exists_primitive_element_iff_finite_intermediateField`: a finite extension `E / F` has a primitive element if and only if the intermediate fields between `E / F` are finitely many.
Also known as Steinitz Theorem <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primitive_element_theorem#The_theorems>.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #7957

nodes.body: Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.

Finally the proof is sorry-free. 😄

By the way, I added a lemma `IntermediateField.finiteDimensional_adjoin_of_finite_of_isAlgebraic` at L296, but it turns out that this lemma is unused. Should I remove that lemma?

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#7957~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

> generalize to `0 ≤ m ≠ n`;

I think this should be easy; I'll try it at next day.

> show `[F⟮α⟯ : F⟮α ^ m⟯] = m` if `m > 0` and `α` transcendental.

I think maybe you can prove directly that `1, α, ... , α ^ (m-1)` form a basis of `F⟮α⟯` as a `F⟮α ^ m⟯`-vector space?

Or perhaps more generally, `[F⟮α⟯ : F⟮Polynomial.aeval α f⟯] = m` if `f : F[X]` with `m = f.natDegree > 0` and `α` transcendental

> I think maybe you can prove directly that 1, α, ... , α ^ (m-1) form a basis of F⟮α⟯ as a F⟮α ^ m⟯-vector space?

> Or perhaps more generally, [F⟮α⟯ : F⟮Polynomial.aeval α f⟯] = m if f : F[X] with m = f.natDegree > 0 and α transcendental

Yeah, both are true. A PowerBasis follows once you show irreducibility of the polynomial (which implies it's the minimal polynomial of α over F⟮α ^ m⟯). A direct proof of linear independence would also be feasible, more so for the similar statement about Algebra.adjoin, but for IntermediateField.adjoin you can still clear the denominators and the proof is essentially the same. I'm not sure it's easier than the proof using irreducibility though.

For the more general statement, actually you can take any rational function `f/g` in α, and the degree of the field extension of `[F(α⟯ : F⟮f(α)/g(α)⟯]` will be `max {deg f, deg g}` assuming `f` and `g` are coprime. For this general result, the Eisenstein criterion no longer applies, but there's actually a simpler proof that generalizes: wlog we may assume `deg g < deg f` because we may replace `f/g` by `g/f`, or in case `deg f = deg g`, replace it by `1/(f/g-1)`. We may further assume `f` is monic, so that the candidate minimal polynomial `f(X)-g(X)Y` of `f(α)/g(α)` is also monic as a polynomial in X, so we can use integral closedness of `F[Y]` to reduce irreducibility problem to the ring `F[Y][X]` as before. But this polynomial is of degree 1 in Y, so its factors are pretty easy to analyze: if it's a product then one of the factors must be of degree 0 in Y, so a polynomial in X, which must be a unit because it needs to divide both f and g.
Sorry for messing around with `Adjoin`. I added two new lemmas and make some of them `simp` lemmas. Is that OK?
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6822911201/job/18555813802)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6822911201/job/18555813434)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6822911201/job/18555814179)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Will take a closer look later
Thanks, looks great to me now!

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
You should move this hypothesis before the colon
This lemma should go in a different file
This is removed in favor of existing `finrank_top`

```suggestion
  simp only at hx hy
```
but this line may not even be needed?
Can't this be `intro x hx` (or better yet `rintro x \<hx,\<hx\>\>`)
It's copied from L121-L125. 😅 By the way, the `rintro` seems not working.
Sorry I'll try and check my comments work next time ;) still I think something like that should be possible
It works, but should be `rintro x (hx | hx)`. Thanks!

```suggestion
    toFun x := x.1
```
should work,
you dont really need the commas here either hopefully

No it does not work 😭
```
Error: ./././Mathlib/FieldTheory/PrimitiveElement.lean:284:11: error: unexpected token ':='; expected ':' or '}'
```
I don't think these are good names, if these lemmas would be useful for any other proof they should get descriptive names, if not they should be `private`
I don't think they are useful in other places *yet*. The `aux_1` may be more useful, but let me make both of them `private` for now.
this lemma seems to be true quite generally, I think it should probably move somewhere where people might find it. It could probably also be generalized a bit to domains at least

I suspect that it should be true when `E` is a Noetherian integrally closed domain. But currently let's stick to UFD. Maybe it should be moved to next to the statement that `E[X]` is a UFD whenever `E` is a UFD.
Moved to `Polynomial.fintypeSubtypeMonicDvd`.
maybe "finite in number"?
Originally I said "if and only if there are only finitely many intermediate fields ..." but it exceeds 100 characters on that line.
Feel free to split the line, and there's no obligation fitting as many as you could in a line! I usually leave some room for possible future edits.
The conclusion should simply be `K ≤ K'` which can be easily converted to this using [inf_eq_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Lattice.html#inf_eq_left).
Is `$` really necessary here? Note that `$` is basically deprecated in favor of `<|`, but here you might just use `(D[X])` which is still quite readable (if it is necessary).

```suggestion
      intro K β ⟨α, hK⟩
```
(maybe rintro, untested)
It works. PS: This code is copied from L232-L233. 😅
This should be generalized to `IsScalarTower F K E` (of (Comm)Rings), not just IntermediateField.
But I don't know how to convert between `Algebra.adjoin` and `IntermediateField.adjoin` ☹
Currently I only provide an `IntermediateField` version. Is it better to also provide an `Algebra` version?

That would be reasonable. There is [IntermediateField.adjoin_eq_algebra_adjoin](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Adjoin.html#IntermediateField.adjoin_eq_algebra_adjoin) but we should have a version assuming E/F is algebraic, then the inv_mem condition is automatic.

The forward direction also holds if `E/F` is only algebraic (with finite dimensionality implied by the LHS), and the backward direction should hold for any extension `E/F`, with algebraicity and finite dimensionality implied by the RHS.
It complains about `[Algebra.IsAlgebraic F E]` because `Algebra.IsAlgebraic` is not a class. So I have to write `(halg : Algebra.IsAlgebraic F E)`.
Yeah, indeed you have to do that when it's not a class. Having a FiniteDimensional version might be more convenient, but I doubt this theorem will be used very often ...

[Polynomial.lifts](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Polynomial/Lifts.html#Polynomial.lifts) is exactly designed for such situation but is little known. Sorry for not mentioning earlier!
Quite weird (and fortunate) that `rw [adjoin_eq_top_of_adjoin_eq_top F K E hprim]` doesn't result in a "motive not type correct error" and requires introduction of no instance.
This lemma should remain private, but I think the `K = K'` version (restated in terms of `Function.Injective`) is potentially useful outside of this file.
Can you suggest a name for the `Function.Injective` version of the lemma?

Actually, I think it's not harder to prove `K` is generated by the coefficients of `(minpoly K α).map (algebraMap K E)`, which would trivially imply injectivity, and would be of more value to mathlib.
I think it's a good idea. It can be named `IntermediateField.eq_adjoin_minpoly_coeff_of_exists_primitive_element`?
Sounds good to me!

Many theorems in this file could have `⊤` replaced with an arbitrary intermediate field, which would make them more easily applicable, even though there's no new mathematical content. Maybe in a future PR?
I'm not sure since I haven't read that code before; it was already here when I add new contents.

My motivation for mentioning this is: the proof of the theorem `exists_primitive_element_of_finite_intermediateField` in the infinite case actually shows that every intermediate field (not just \top) have a primitive element, but in the finite case, we'd need to generalize this theorem. If that's done, we can safely mark the auxiliary result `primitive_element_inf_aux_of_finite_intermediateField` private, because it would be syntactically a specialization of the theorem.

Yes, I think `primitive_element_inf_aux_of_finite_intermediateField` is a special case of `exists_primitive_element_of_finite_intermediateField` if the latter is changed a slightly. For others I think it's better for a future PR/issue.

The next thing to do is to prove the `IsSeparable` version of the theorem `exists_primitive_element` using `exists_primitive_element_of_finite_intermediateField`, and then this long proof can be removed.

The key ingredient would be [IsGalois.intermediateFieldEquivSubgroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Galois.html#IsGalois.intermediateFieldEquivSubgroup), but that need to be applied to the SplittingField, so some maneuvers would be required.
Oh that would be circular ... would require refactoring the proof of `card_aut_eq_finrank`, which is definitely out of scope of this PR.
Maybe it's related to separable degree of field extension <https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Separability.20degree.3F>?

Indeed since there is [Normal.algHomEquivAut](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Normal.html#Normal.algHomEquivAut), so we're done once you show the separable degree of a separable extension is equal to its degree.
Why do you use instance-implicit argument [Finite (IntermediateField F E)] above in `primitive_element_inf_aux_of_finite_intermediateField` but switched to explicit here?
There are still various TODO here.

```suggestion
theorem lift_adjoin (K : IntermediateField F E) (S : Set K) :
    lift (L := E) (E := adjoin F S) = adjoin F (Subtype.val '' S) :=
  adjoin_map _ _
```

Sorry it does not work:
```
Error: ./././Mathlib/FieldTheory/Adjoin.lean:440:2: error: type mismatch
  adjoin_map ?m.759025 ?m.759030
has type
  ∀ (f : ?m.759027 →ₐ[?m.759025] ?m.759031),
    map f (adjoin ?m.759025 ?m.759030) = adjoin ?m.759025 (↑f '' ?m.759030) : Prop
but is expected to have type
  lift (adjoin F S) = adjoin F (Subtype.val '' S) : Prop
```
Change to `adjoin_map ..` works, though.
With #7957, the proof should just be `map_bot`
`Fintype` instances shouldn't really be noncomputable; I think this would be better suited as a `Finite` instance.
The proof uses `UniqueFactorizationMonoid.fintypeSubtypeDvd` which is a `noncomputable def` of `Fintype`. For API consistency I also used `Fintype` for this result.

I think we'd like to eventually replace that by `Finite` as well. It's the remnant of previous suboptimal practices.. Or maybe Fintype necessary because it's a type that we apply `Finset.sum` to, but it's not the case here.

Thanks for taking up my challenge. The proofs you come up with are nice and direct. The proof of `finiteDimensional_of_finite_intermediateField` was unexpected to me: the proof I have in mind is to keep adjoining elements to build an infinite chain of intermediate fields.

However, the statement of this theorem is still a bit sub-mathlib-standard, but I don't think it's worth spending much more efforts on it, so I left a to-do item as a comment.
Oh, I haven't think of your generalizations before. It looks cool. 😄 But is it correct?

Do you mean [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7788/commits/03ea98ffef8ddb7136916992559b42bd626f7d11)? Sorry for the oversight, I was operating in proof-by-contradiction mode.

`[F⟮X⟯ : F⟮X^m⟯] = m` corresponds to the fact that `X -> X^m` is a degree m self-(branched)-cover of P^1.
To show the equality you mostly just need to prove the polynomial `X^m-Y : F⟮Y⟯[X]` is irreducible. Since `F⟮Y⟯` is the fraction field of `F[Y]` (which is integrally closed), by [Polynomial.Monic.irreducible_iff_irreducible_map_fraction_map](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Polynomial/GaussLemma.html#Polynomial.Monic.irreducible_iff_irreducible_map_fraction_map) you reduce to showing it's irreducible in F[Y][X], where you can use [Polynomial.irreducible_of_eisenstein_criterion](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/EisensteinCriterion.html#Polynomial.irreducible_of_eisenstein_criterion). You will need to develop some API around `transcendental`, e.g. show that F⟮α⟯ is isomorphic to F⟮Y⟯=Frac F[Y] when α is transcendental. (Currently [loogle](https://loogle.lean-lang.org/?q=Transcendental) returns exactly 5 result 😢 )

A few more missing APIs:

+ An AlgHom between two extensions induces an OrderEmbedding between the IntermediateField types (in particular `IntermediateField.lift` is injective). An AlgEquiv induces an OrderEquiv.

+ A transcendental element α over F induces an AlgEquiv between F⟮α⟯ and [RatFunc](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/RatFunc.html#RatFunc) F.

Then you can just show that `RatFunc F` over `F` has infinitely many intermediate fields. But at some point you still need to identify the intermediate field `F⟮X^m⟯` with `RatFunc F` itself ...

```suggestion
-- TODO: generalize to 0 ≤ m ≠ n; show [F⟮α⟯ : F⟮α ^ m⟯] = m if m > 0 and α transcendental.
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FieldTheory/PrimitiveElement): Steinitz Theorem
